journal-title-group.journal-title: bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology

title-group.article-title: Quantitative analysis of gas chromatography-coupled electroantennographic detection (GC-EAD) of plant volatiles by insects

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Cell and Developmental Biology, https://ror.org/055zmrh94John Innes Centre, https://ror.org/0062dz060Norwich Research Park, Norwich, NR4 7UH, United Kingdom

author-notes.corresp: To whom correspondence may be addressed: Kelsey.Byers@jic.ac.uk; robert.n.jacobs@gmail.com

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY-NC 4.0 International license.

sec.title: Premise
sec.p: Plant-interacting insects receive plant volatile signals through their antennae, and voltage changes across an antenna exposed to volatile stimuli can be measured to determine if insects can perceive them, often by coupling gas chromatography to electroantennographic detection (GC-EAD). Current methods for analysing GC-EAD data rely on qualitative observation, rather than using quantitative analysis, and are thus prone to bias.

sec.title: Methods and Results
sec.p: We developed a novel quantitative methodology for analysis of GC-EAD data using a signal processing technique on EAD data to compare responses of hawkmoths and bumble bees to a library of common floral volatiles. Responses varied between species and sexes and these responses were in some cases affected by compound type or modification.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Our novel GC-EAD analysis technique is robust to baseline drift and low signal:noise ratios commonly found in GC-EAD data, and provides a way forward for quantitative studies of plant volatile-mediated plant-insect interactions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Plants produce a wide array of secondary metabolites – i.e. those that are not immediately tied to growth and reproduction – with over 200,000 isolated and described across the plant kingdom (Kessler and Kalske, 2018). Many of these compounds play direct roles in the interactions of plants with the abiotic and biotic environment, and have been exploited for this purpose by humanity, including the agricultural (e.g. geraniol, a terpenoid volatile, which repels eggplant-infesting pest moths (Ghosh et al., 2023; Byers, 2023)) and flavour and fragrance industries (e.g. vanillin, a volatile product of the phenylpropanoid pathway, which is the dominant compound in natural vanilla extract (Gallage et al., 2014)). Although these compounds can be exploited in such ways, and although chemical structures of numerous plant metabolites have been described, their biological functions remain unknown in many cases (Dixon and Dickinson, 2024). Many of these compounds are volatiles, which are especially well known for influencing plants’ interactions with insects by attracting both beneficial and antagonistic species (e.g. pollinators and herbivores (Raguso, 2008)), with significant implications for plant ecology and evolution (Byers, 2021) as well as agriculture (Pickett and Khan, 2016).

Identifying which volatile cues emitted by plants are perceived by plant-interacting insects is key to our understanding of these cross-kingdom interactions. In particular, identifying insect-relevant volatiles can facilitate work in plant secondary metabolism, ecology, and evolution. For example, identifying pest-resistant crop varieties by screening for known resistance volatiles is cheaper and easier than performing field trials (e.g. Ghosh et al., 2023), while determining which volatiles are key to the ecology and evolution of plant-pollinator interactions can facilitate genetic mapping of only those volatiles rather than the entire plant headspace (e.g. Byers et al., 2014a, 2014b). In short, identifying insect-relevant volatiles – often only a fraction of a plant’s emitted volatiles and individually not always the most abundant volatiles (Clavijo McCormick et al., 2014) – can dramatically reduce the experimental scope and increase the tractability of plant secondary metabolite study.

Electroantennography – the detection and measurement of electrical signals from whole insect antennae – is often used to screen plant volatiles for insect perceptibility. The compounds to which the insect antenna “responds” with some voltage change are taken to be physiologically active and may be further tested via behavioural assays with single pure or mixed compounds or with plant lines known to be high or low in the relevant compounds. Although these techniques have been in use for nearly seventy years, being first described in 1957 (Schneider, 1957), the resulting data are always presented qualitatively – “response/no response” (e.g. Peakall et al., 2010) – with no quantitative, repeatable measure used to define antennal “response” versus background activity. Indeed, a comprehensive and well-cited overview of GC-EAD includes no mention of how data analysis is performed or what criteria are used to define an “active” peak (Schiestl and Marion-Poll, 2002). This has hampered the field by limiting reproducibility and cross-study or cross-observer comparisons, introducing error, and reducing ease of application to broader plant volatile studies. This may be a particular issue with many plant volatiles, which – unlike insect pheromones – may not have the same degree of “dedicated hardware” on the insect antenna (Akers and Getz, 1993; Schiestl and Marion-Poll, 2002) and thus may produce weaker signals, with the exception of sexually deceptive insect pollination systems which use insect pheromone compounds to attract pollinators.

In this Protocol Note, I present “best practice” statistical approaches incorporating techniques from signal processing to analyse gas chromatography-coupled electroantennographic detection (GC-EAD) data in a quantitative fashion. Methods for correcting for baseline drift (specifically, the use of the antennal signal first forward difference), background antennal noise (specifically, comparison with response to the solvent control), and antennal sensitivity loss (via use of windowing) are presented. A sample data set from six Manduca sexta hawkmoths (three males and three females), four Bombus terrestris audax bumble bees (all workers), and 28 common volatile stimuli of different volatile chemical skeleton types (all present in a variety of plant species) are used to demonstrate the methods and their application in detail and show that they work for a variety of volatile plant secondary metabolites and two major model pollinating insect species. I show that quantitative analyses of electroantennogram data are indeed possible and quite feasible, pointing the way forward for robust, statistically-based analyses of antennal detection ability in volatile-driven plant-insect interactions.

sec.title: Methods: Gas chromatography-coupled electroantennographic detection (GC-EAD) setup and recording
Insect sourcing
sec.p: Adult Manduca sexta (L.) (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae) hawkmoth males and females were sourced from a maintained colony reared on artificial diet (Frontiers Scientific Services, Newark, Delaware, USA) at the John Innes Centre Entomology platform facility; adults were not fed but females were allowed to oviposit freely on live Nicotiana benthamiana plants and males and females were kept together prior to collection. Worker Bombus terrestris audax (Harris) (Hymenoptera: Apidae) were sourced from a single Bumblebee New Season Hive (Biobest, purchased from Agralan Ltd, Wiltshire, UK) which were allowed to freely forage in a custom-built acrylic cage with 25% sucrose and ground pollen ad libitum (Sevenhills Wholefoods Organic Raw Bee Pollen, Dinnington, UK).

sec.title: EAD test mixture preparation and analysis
sec.p: To assess antennal responses to multiple compounds delivered at approximately equal flame ionization detector (FID) sensitivities, a mixture of 28 authentic reference standards was assembled, representing 29 GC-FID peaks (farnesol is sold as a mixture of isomers and both elute separately on the GC-FID). Standards were obtained from a variety of established sources (see Table S1 for vendor addresses and Table S2 for vendor and product numbers) and diluted to 10μg/μl in hexane (HPLC-grade, ca. 95% purity). The final compound list was selected to include a variety of chemical skeletons (terpenoids, aromatics, fatty acid derived compounds, and one nitrogenous compound) that would separate well on a 10°C per minute GC oven ramp program. Due to differences in FID responsiveness to the individual compounds (i.e. some compounds may produce different peak areas on the FID despite being at equal injected amounts), different volumes of the 10μg/μl dilutions were added to the mixture (see Table S2 for final concentrations, which ranged from 93ng/μl for (R)-(+)-limonene to 2004ng/μl (2.004μg/μl) for indole).

To determine retention times and mixture peak identities, 3ul of the test mixture was manually injected into an Agilent 7890BGC (Agilent, Stockport, UK) fitted with an Agilent 5977A/B MS detector (GC-MS) and a Phenomenex Zebron ZB-5HT column (30m x 0.25mm x 0.10μm; Phenomenex UK Ltd, Macclesfield, United Kingdom). The GC run parameters were as follows: the column flow was 1.0603 ml/min of helium carrier gas with an oven program of 50°C for 4 minutes followed by a temperature ramp of 10°C/minute to 230°C, which was then held for 4 minutes. The inlet was splitless and held at 250°C and the MS source was held at 230°C. Compounds were identified using Agilent Unknowns software (v10.1, Agilent, Stockport, UK) and via comparison to Kovats Retention Indices of the individual compounds run separately using the same GC-MS system, calculated using an alkane ladder (49452-U, Sigma-Aldrich, Watford, UK).

sec.title: EAD antennalpreparation and assembly
sec.p: Manduca sexta male and female adults: single antennae were excised using microdissection scissors from three individuals each of living adult male and female Manduca sexta. Due to biosecurity requirements for this non-native potential plant pest species, excised antennae were placed in a 15ml conical tube on wet tissue paper to maintain antennal humidity levels and carried to the electrophysiology setup in a separate building. The fine tip of an antenna (representing ca. 7 segments, cut where the tip abruptly broadens) was removed using a microscalpel under a dissection microscope and the antenna mounted on an antenna electrode fork (Syntech PRG-2) using electrode gel (Signa Gel, Parker Laboratories, Fairfield, New Jersey, USA), which was then plugged in to the electrode mount (Syntech MP-15 with EAG Combi Probe) and moved into position in front of the GC eluent-carrying air stream approximately 1cm from the air stream outlet.

Bombus terrestris audax workers: individuals were removed from the Entomology platform facility in 50ml conical tubes, then kept at 4°C for 30 minutes to enable safe antennal removal. Antennae were then removed using microdissection scissors under red light (with the insect held using a set of forceps) and the tip of the final flagellar segment removed using a microscalpel under a dissection microscope, then treated as above.

sec.title: GC-EAD setup and recording procedure
sec.p: The GC-FID setup consisted of an Agilent 8890 GC fitted with a flame ionization detector (FID). The column (a Phenomenex Zebron ZB-5HT column (35m x 0.25mm x 0.10μm), identical to the one used for GC-MS analysis) was fitted to a splitless inlet kept at 250°C. The detector end of the column was fitted to the bottom end of an inert glass Y-splitter (Agilent UltraInert Universal PressFit Y-Splitter, part 5190-6980). The two other arms of the splitter were fitted with deactivated column segments of equal 30cm length (Agilent CP803210, 0.32mm inner diameter), with one end running to the FID (which was kept at 300°C) and the other end leaving the GC oven through a port on the side which was fitted with a Syntech EC-03 heated transfer tube kept at 250°C. The GC used hydrogen as a carrier gas, which was generated with a Parker Hydrogen Generator (H2PEM-100, Thames Restek UK Ltd, Saunderton, United Kingdom). Nitrogen gas at a flow of 25ml/min was used as a make-up gas, and the FID was also fed with compressed air at 400ml/min to ensure adequate flame gas supply. The GC run parameters were as follows: the column flow was 4.7 ml/min with an oven program of 50°C for 4 minutes followed by a temperature ramp of 10°C/minute to 230°C, which was then held for 4 minutes. Each manual sample injection consisted of 3ul of the EAD test mixture, for a total of 0.279-6.012μg of compound injected. GC-FID chromatogram waveforms were exported from Agilent OpenLab CDS v2.5 software as CSV files consisting of an FID amplitude value (in pA) for each given sampled timepoint.

The EAD recording setup consisted of a Syntech IDAC-2 (Ockenfels Syntech, Buchenbach, Germany) connected to the desktop computer controlling the GC-FIDsystem. A constant air flow (setting 8 on the CS-55) was delivered using a Syntech CS-55 Stimulus Controller throughout the experiment. Prior to and shortly after each GC-FID run, a puff of the EAD test mixture (via a Pasteur pipette fitted with filter paper, with 10μl of the EAD test mixture added onto the paper, also setting 8 on the CS-55) was delivered using the CS-55 to ensure antennal viability had been maintained throughout the GC-FID run. EAD signals were captured using Syntech GcEAD 2014 v1.2.5 software with default settings and exported as CSV waveforms in GcEAD 2014 (measured as millivolts) prior to analysis.

sec.title: GC-FID peak identification
sec.p: A custom Perl script (Perl, 2023; see Appendix for script) was developed to determine the “onset” and “offset” timings (i.e. when a peak began and when it ended) of GC-FID peaks above a certain user-defined threshold from the FID CSV data. In the presented experimental data, the threshold was set at 50pA to capture all significant peaks while avoiding inclusion of small peaks likely representing contamination from the hexane solvent. Note that this resulted in the merger of the closely eluting caryophyllene oxide and ethyl laurate peaks, which were removed from the analyses of compound type and compound modification impact on GC-EAD responses as a result.

sec.title: Data loading and initial processing
sec.p: EAD and FID waveforms were loaded as CSV files into R (R Core Team, 2024; see Appendix for example script). GC-FID onsets and offsets determined in the previous section were also loaded. As the EAD setup samples at a rate of 6000 datapoints per second and does not export a timestamp to its CSV file, a new time variable was defined corresponding to the sampling rate. The GC-FID injection time and a 20 minute endpoint (after all tested peaks had eluted) relative to the EAD time were also defined, as were EAD timestamps corresponding to each GC-FID peak onset and offset. As injections were done manually for the GC-FID, there was occasionally a slight disparity between GC-FID peak onsets and the onset of a significant-seeming EAD pattern, and so a user-defined offset was determined by comparing the most significant EAD pattern onset with the previously determined corresponding GC-FID peak onset.

sec.title: First Forward Difference (FFD) processing and significant FFD value identification
sec.p: Using the diff() function in base R (specifically as ‘diff(EADamplitude,lag=1,differences=1)’), the First Forward Difference of the antennal amplitude was calculated from the input antennal amplitude data. The FFD vector was subsetted into five windows of four minutes each for a total GC-FID run of 20 minutes. For each window, the average and standard deviation of the FFD within that window was calculated. A significance threshold of 3σ above or below the average was calculated, and data points that exceeded the significance threshold for their respective windows were marked as significant.

sec.title: Calculating the number of significant FFD hits per second for each identified GC-FID peak
sec.p: For each GC-FID peak identified, the number of significant hits as defined above within its onset-offset window was determined using the ‘between’ function in the R package dplyr (Wickham et al., 2023). This value was divided by the length of the GC-FID peak in seconds (offset time minus onset time) to get the significant hit frequency of hits/second. As EAD data can have significant background noise (Schiestl and Marion-Poll, 2002), we defined the frequency of the initial hexane peak 1 as the threshold for whether a peak attracted significant EAD activity: if the frequency for a given GC-FID peak exceeded the frequency of the hexane peak, it was counted as significant, and otherwise considered insignificant.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: A “significant response” across each species-sex/caste category (female M. sexta, male M. sexta, and worker B. terrestris) was identified for compounds where >50% of individuals tested showed a significant hit frequency greater than that of the initial large solvent (hexane) peak.

To investigate whether the results were repeatable between moths, we calculated the Pearson correlation coefficient between the significant hit frequency for each pair of moths within a sex using cor.test() in R. We repeated this test with a binary vector (1 = GC-FID peak had a significant hit frequency; 0 = it did not). We then used lm() in R to calculate the slope and intercept of the relationship between each pair of moths within a sex. Finally, we used lm() and emmeans() (Lenth, 2024) to determine whether compound skeletal or modification type had an influence on significant hit frequency within each species-sex/caste group (female M. sexta, male M. sexta, and worker B. terrestris).

sec.title: The new method allows quantitative analysis and avoids baseline drift
sec.p: Traditional GC-EAD analysis is done in a visual qualitative fashion by comparing GC-FID peak timings with EAD readouts by eye (e.g. comparison of Figure 1A with Figure 1B, see also Figures S1-S15). It also suffers from baseline drift and signal noise, two phenomena that make it difficult to detect whether an EAD data point is indeed a “significant” response to a GC-provided stimulus or not (Schiestl and Marion-Poll, 2002). As the antenna degrades over time and accommodates in the long term to compound stimuli (see Byers et al., 2020), antennal responsiveness and the ability to detect significant responses by eye also degrades and the noise level often increases, also impeding qualitative visual comparison of GC-FID and EAD data.

Here we present a method that avoids the otherwise significant biases inherent in GC-EAD qualitative analysis methodology by the use of a signal processing technique, the first forward difference (FFD), to remove the influence of baseline drift, essentially flattening out the EAD signal and replacing its waveform with a series of individual spikes (Figure 1C, see also Figures S16-S30). A significance threshold may then be set for each window (horizontal lines in Figure 1C and Figures S16-S30, both showing ± 3 standard deviations above/below the mean for that window), and the frequency of spikes with an amplitude over that significance threshold during a given GC-FID peak may be easily calculated and analysed using traditional statistical methods. This results in a quantitative rather than qualitative assessment of whether a GC-EAD peak is physiologically active or not.

sec.title: GC-FID peaks with significant EAD responses
sec.p: Table 1 shows the list of compounds tested in the EAD test mixture along with their response rates for female and male moths and worker bumble bees and how many individuals of each had a response rate over that of the main hexane peak. In general, female moths were most responsive to fatty acid-derived compounds (FADs, red in Figure 2A, see also Figure S31) and to some but not all aromatic volatiles (blue in Figure 2A). Responses to terpenoids were more mixed (green in Figure 2A), with some compounds (e.g. (1S)-(-)-verbenone) eliciting significant responses, while others (e.g. camphene) eliciting no significant responses at all. The sole tested nitrogenous compound, indole (yellow in Figure 2A), did not elicit significant responses in female moths. Overall, female moths responded significantly to 15 of the 31 tested compounds (excluding the hexane peaks). Male moths were far less responsive than females to the majority of compounds, with overall significant responses to only fourof the 31 tested compounds (excluding the hexane peaks) and with no significant difference in response between compound skeleton types (Figure S31A,B). Worker bumble bees responded significantly to 10 of the 31 compounds. Bees responded equally to all types of compound classes (Figure S31C), although there was no response to indole, the sole nitrogenous compound tested, in any bee.

Compounds containing oxygenated modifications seemed to produce the highest level of response in female moths, but not in males (Figure S31D,E). Females responded significantly to 6 of 10 presented esters (analyzed without the co-eluting peaks ethyl laurate and caryophyllene oxide), 2/6 alcohols, 3/3 aldehydes, and 3/3 ketones, but not to any of the five presented unmodified monoterpenes ((1R)-α-pinene, camphene, and R-(+)-limonene) or sesquiterpenes (caryophyllene, α-humulene), both groups of which lack oxygen atoms. Male moths responded to 1 of 10 esters, 0/6 alcohols, 1/3 aldehydes, and 0/3 ketones but, similarly to females, only responded to 1/5 of the unmodified (mono/sesqui)terpenes. Both females and males also responded significantly overall to the “Unknown 2” compound, whose identity remains unclear despite GC-MS analysis but which likely also is oxygenated based on tentative NIST library matches. For bees, there was no difference in response based on compound modification, oxygenated or otherwise (Figure S31F). Bees responded to 3 of 10 esters, 3/6 alcohols, 1/3 aldehydes, 2/3 ketones, and 1/5 unmodified (mono/sesqui)terpenes.

sec.title: Repeatability within moth sexes and comparisons between sexes
sec.p: Responses to non-hexane compounds were highly repeatable between female moths (Figure S32A, Pearson’s correlation coefficient range 0.265 to 0.637, all P < 3×10-7), but not between male moths (Figure S32B, Pearson’s correlation coefficient range −0.238 to −0.054, all P ≥ 0.20). In general, male moths were substantially less responsive to non-hexane chemical stimuli in this experiment, as represented by their much lower average significant hit frequency (Table 1, range 0-4.000 significant hits/second) versus females (range 0-21.919 significant hits/second). Responses between males and females were generally uncorrelated (Pearson’s r = 0.073, P = 0.696, Figure S33). The only two compounds that resulted in significant hit frequencies in ≥ 2/3 of moths of both sexes were phenylacetaldehyde and “Unknown 1”.

sec.title: Repeatability and feasibility across species and comparison to existing literature
sec.p: To ensure that our results were not simply due to some property of Manduca sexta antennae, we also analysed the same stimulus mixture with four workers of the polylectic (wide dietary breadth, Rasmont et al., 2008) bumble bee Bombus terrestris audax using the same data collection and analysis methodologies. We found no compounds that were significant in >50% of tested individuals across all three species-sex/caste combinations (female hawkmoths, male hawkmoths, worker bumble bees). However, we did identify a short list of compounds that were significant in >50% of tested individuals for both female Manduca sexta and worker Bombus terrestris audax, namely benzaldehyde, (Z)-3-hexenyl acetate, acetophenone, (1S)-(-)-verbenone, and geraniol (Table 1). Results from individuals of all three groups are presented in Figure 3. We also observed overall weaker responses in bumble bees compared with hawkmoths, despite robust responses to single puffs of the EAD stimulus mixture. The signal to noise threshold in the bumble bee antennae appears to be weaker than in the hawkmoths (as shown by much lower first forward difference significance thresholds and a lower range of significant average hit frequencies (range 0-1.752 hits/second compared with hawkmoth values of 0-21.919 and 0-4.000 for females and males respectively). We separately conducted a somewhat haphazard literature review to identify whether our tested compounds had previously been identified as electroantennographically active in either Manduca sexta or Bombus terrestris, with the results shown in Table S3. In general, many of our tested compounds had not previously been tested with GC-EAD or puff-based electroantennography, and those that had been often produced results that differed between studies, further suggesting the need for a quantitative analysis technique such as the one presented here.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this Protocol Note, we have presented a novel signal processing-based methodology for use with gas chromatography-coupled electroantennographic detection (GC-EAD) measurements of insect antennae in response to plant volatiles. Female Manduca sexta hawkmoths were responsive to approximately half of tested compounds in a highly repeatable fashion, while male hawkmoths of the same species responded to only about one eighth of tested compounds and were far less repeatable between individuals. In female moths, compound skeleton type (FAD, aromatic, terpenoid, or nitrogenous) and modification (none, alcohol, aldehyde, ester, ketone, or oxide) played a significant role in response patterns, while in male moths this was only true for modification type but not compound skeleton type. Worker Bombus terrestris audax bumble bees showed an intermediate level of response, with significant responses to one third of tested compounds, and with no difference in response rate relative to compound type or modification.

Our haphazard literature review to identify compounds that had previously been identified as electroantennographically active in either Manduca sexta or Bombus terrestris identified large gaps in our knowledge, as well as discrepancies between studies in whether compounds were designated as physiologically active or not in the antenna. Consistent with our findings, some compounds were significant in some studies but not others, emphasizing the importance of testing stimuli on multiple individuals of a given species rather than relying on one or two individuals, given that we found variability even between individuals of the same commercial bumble bee hive and hawkmoth colony. The weaker responses seen in bumble bees further necessitate the use of this new technique to ensure unbiased assessment of electroantennographic detection studies in potentially less strongly responsive insects.

By studying responses to common plant volatiles in two model pollinator species, we have shown that responses are species- and sex-specific, and that it will be difficult to generalize results from one pollinator group to another. Further study will be needed to determine whether results can be generalized within a genus of pollinators, or between those that are generalists and specialists. However, at least one species of pollinating insect was responsive to the majority of the plant compounds tested here. Interestingly, there was no significant GC-EAD response in any species tested to the monoterpene (R)-(+)-limonene. Limonene is the most widely distributed floral volatile in terms of angiosperm families in which it is found (Schiestl, 2010), and is known to provoke a responsive in the antennal lobe of Bombus vosnesenskii (Byers et al., 2014a). We also did not see any response to the common nitrogenous volatile indole. The latter is utilized in many dung-mimicking brood site-deceptive pollination systems (Jürgens et al., 2013), which does not include the insects tested here.

The methods introduced make use of existing typical GC-EAD recording setups and methods, differing only in the downstream processing of collected GC-EAD data, and thus may be used with both existing as well as novel datasets. In addition, they are simple to execute, requiring only minimal implementation in R or another statistical processing language (example code is provided in the Appendix). This study provides the first truly quantitative analysis of insect responses to common plant volatiles using GC-EAD, and paves the way forward for future GC-EAD analyses to incorporate quantitative, unbiased data processing methodologies to determine whether plant volatiles are physiologically active to interacting insect species.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors thank the John Innes Centre (JIC) Entomology platform for maintaining the Manduca sexta and Bombus terrestris colonies and the JIC Metabolomics platform for GC-MS maintenance. Funding was provided by the UK Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council Institute Strategic Programmes (Harnessing Biosynthesis for Sustainable Food and Health (HBio) (grant no. BB/X01097X/1) and Building Robustness in Crops (BRiC) (grant no. BB/X01102X/1)). We also thank anonymous reviewers and the editor for their helpfulsuggestions.

sec.title: Data Availability
sec.p: All raw data (GC-FID CSV files, electroantennography CSV files, and relevant GC-FID injection timestamps) are available on FigShare (doi: XXX). Scripts referenced in the main text and appendices are also available on GitHub ().

fn.p: KJRPB conceived the project, designed and executed the data collection and data analysis methodology, and wrote the manuscript. RNJ contributed significant signal processing methodology ideas and expertise to the data analysis methodology development. Both authors approved the final version of the manuscript.

caption.title: Comparison of raw EAD and first forward difference-processed EAD traces from a single female Manduca sexta hawkmoth antenna between 4-8 minutes of GC elapsed time.
caption.p: (A) GC-FID trace annotated with automatically detected peak starts and ends (colored vertical lines) and peak identities. (B) Raw EAD amplitude annotated with GC-FID peak starts and ends. (C) First forward difference-processed EAD amplitude annotated with GC-FID peak starts and ends. Note the “wandering baseline” in (B) that is absent in (C).

First forward difference-processed EAD responses to 33 compounds from the test mixture, colored by compound type (note that the Y-axis scaling differs for (C)). Note for caryophyllene oxide*: this box includes responses to ethyl laurate, as the peaks were merged in the GC-FID annotation thresholding step so are treated as a single peak by the analysis. (A) Data from three Manduca sexta females. (B) Data from three Manduca sexta males. (C) Data from four Bombus terrestris audax workers.

Antennal responses of three female Manduca sexta (“MsextaF*1-3+”), three male Manduca sexta (“MsextaM*1-3+”), and four Bombus terrestris audax workers (“Bterr*1-4+”) expressed as a ratio of the significant hit frequency of each compound to that of the significant hit frequency of the initial hexane solvent peak (“value”), with warmer colors and larger circles denoting higher ratios and blue and smaller circles denoting lower ratios. Absent points indicate the specific peak was not detected in the GC-FID run for a given insect.

Compounds used in the EAD test mixture with details of their retention time, compound skeleton type and subtype or modification categorization, and average significant hit frequency (spikes per second, bold text indicates higher than first hexane peak frequency for that species and sex/caste) for female and male Manduca sexta hawkmoths and worker Bombus terrestris audax bumble bees. The ratio after the significant hit frequency indicates the number of samples where the given compound elicited a greater response than the main hexane peak versus the total number of samples with that peak present (bold: >50% of samples reacted to that peak for a given species-sex/caste combination). Unknown superscripts: 1A: an unclear oxygenated cyclic molecule from GC-MS results; 2B: likely an unknown sesquiterpenoid oxide from GC-MS analysis results.

tr.th: Retent ion time (GC- FID, minute s)
Average Manduca sexta female response (significant hit frequency, spikes/second)
Average Manduca sexta male response (significant hit frequency, spikes/secon d)
Average Bombus terrestris audax worker response (significant hit frequency, spikes/second)

tr.td: Caryophyllene oxide + ethyl laurate (peaks merged by FID peak identification script)
